pullRequest.body:
Many of the existing induction lemmas for subobjects (e.g., `Subsemigroup.closure_induction`) were written with a motive that does not depend on the induction argument (e.g., `x âˆˆ Subsemigroup.closure s`), like so:

```lean
theorem Subsemigroup.closure_induction {M : Type u_1} [Mul M] {s : Set M}
    {p : M â†’ Prop} {x : M} (h : x âˆˆ Subsemigroup.closure s)
    (mem : âˆ€ x âˆˆ s, p x) (mul : âˆ€ (x y : M), p x â†’ p y â†’ p (x * y)) :
    p x
```

This prevents Lean from correctly inferring the motive when applying the `induction` tactic. As such, these lemmas don't serve much purpose, and we gradually acquired their dependent counterparts as variations with a `'`, like this one:

```lean
theorem Subsemigroup.closure_induction' {M : Type u_1} [Mul M] (s : Set M)
    {p : (x : M) â†’ x âˆˆ Subsemigroup.closure s â†’ Prop}
    (mem : âˆ€ (x : M) (h : x âˆˆ s), p x â‹¯)
    (mul : âˆ€ (x : M) (hx : x âˆˆ Subsemigroup.closure s) (y : M)
    (hy : y âˆˆ Subsemigroup.closure s), p x hx â†’ p y hy â†’ p (x * y) (mul_mem hx hy))
    {x : M} (hx : x âˆˆ Subsemigroup.closure s) :
    p x hx
```

This PR moves the primed versions to the un-primed names, and removes the non-dependent lemmas, while also ensuring the dependent versions exist and are uniform for all these various subobjects.

Moves:

- Subsemigroup.closure_induction' -> Subsemigroup.closure_induction
- AddSubsemigroup.closure_induction' -> AddSubsemigroup.closure_induction
- Submonoid.closure_induction' -> Submonoid.closure_induction
- AddSubmonoid.closure_induction' -> AddSubmonoid.closure_induction
- Subgroup.closure_induction' -> Subgroup.closure_induction
- AddSubgroup.closure_induction' -> AddSubgroup.closure_induction
- Submodule.span_induction' -> Submodule.span_induction
- Submodule.closure_induction' -> Submodule.closure_induction
- NonUnitalAlgebra.adjoin_induction' -> NonUnitalAlgebra.adjoin_induction
- NonUnitalStarAlgebra.adjoin_induction' -> NonUnitalStarAlgebra.adjoin_induction
- Subsemiring.closure_induction' -> Subsemiring.closure_induction
- Subring.closure_induction' -> Subring.closure_induction
- Algebra.adjoin_induction'' -> Algebra.adjoin_induction

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [217d8387b3](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17543/commits/217d8387b36ee893f3ae73d27ab52b33bc00107d)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ adjoin_induction_subtype`
`++++++------ closure_induction'`
`+++---++++---- closure_inductionâ‚‚`
`+++----+++++---- closure_induction`
`++-++-- adjoin_induction`
`++-- dense_induction`
`++--- adjoin_induction'`
`-++--+ adjoin_inductionâ‚‚`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

It's great that we add these dependent induction lemmas, but I think it's sometimes nice to also have access to the non-dependent ones, since they're sometimes easier to work with. For example, when it's necessary to specify the motive to a dependent induction in the case where the application is not dependent, you often end up with things looking syntactically really confusing. I'd personally slightly prefer keeping the old ones around, under other names. But if it turns out that adjusting mathlib to your change is easy enough, then it's probably fine...

You should never have to specify the motive explicitly though? Usually when you do, this is because:
* The induction principle was not dependent, and should have been
* The induction principle has the arguments in the wrong order
* `elab_as_elim` is missing from the theorem
* You tried to use `apply` with an `elab_as_elim`

> You should never have to specify the motive explicitly though? 

Note that the current state of this PR has exactly one adaptation going from the non-dependent to the dependent one, in `dense_induction`. And the motive is specified explicitly here, in a non-dependent way: exactly the situation I'm worried about. 
It's possible that this is an isolated example, but I just want to flag it because it does get annoying in practice.

@b-mehta I *think* that `refine` can get confused, but that's primarily because `dense_induction` is weird in that the term on which we are doing induction (namely `x`) doesn't reference `s` in it's type, so it's a bit underdetermined. Nevertheless, I think Eric is right, so long as you actually use the `induction` tactic. For instance, this works for `Subsemigroup.dense_induction`.
```lean
theorem dense_induction {p : M â†’ Prop} {s : Set M} (hs : closure s = âŠ¤)
    (mem : âˆ€ x âˆˆ s, p x)
    (mul : âˆ€ x y, p x â†’ p y â†’ p (x * y))
    (x : M) : p x := by
  induction hs.symm â–¸ mem_top x using closure_induction with
  | mem x hx => exact mem x hx
  | mul x _ y _ hpx hpy => exact mul x y hpx hpy
```

Overall, while it was a lot of work to go through changing things, it wasn't terrible. This `dense_induction` issue hardly ever came up (at least in terms of *new* places where I needed to specify the motive). You're welcome to have a look and let me know what you think.
I think all the primed induction principles should be kept as deprecated aliases, to not break downstream code that already uses them.

> I think all the primed induction principles should be kept as deprecated aliases, to not break downstream code that already uses them.

I considered that, but I think it might be really confusing if we *only* swap the names on some of them.

> > I think all the primed induction principles should be kept as deprecated aliases, to not break downstream code that already uses them.
> 
> I considered that, but I think it might be really confusing if we _only_ swap the names on some of them.

I'm not suggesting we swap the names, but that both the primed and unprimed versions refer to the dependent ones. That way people don't have to guess to work out that they just need to remove the `'`.

> I'm not suggesting we swap the names, but that both the primed and unprimed versions refer to the dependent ones. That way people don't have to guess to work out that they just need to remove the `'`

Done

ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by b-mehta.

Given that this PR is huge, I thoroughly approve of the changes, my questions above are quite superficial and probably easily answered, and this might pick up merge conflicts if we leave it too long, my instinct is to merge first and ask questions later.

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11355371773/job/31584562609)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11355371773/job/31584562939)
I'm curious if you can drop the `(subset_closure hz)` here; I think it can be found by unification?
yes, it can.

```suggestion
    (mul_left : âˆ€ x hx y hy z hz, p x z hx hz â†’ p y z hy hz â†’ p (x * y) z (mul_mem hx hy) hz)
    (mul_right : âˆ€ x hx y hy z hz, p z x hz hx â†’ p z y hz hy â†’ p z (x * y) hz (mul_mem hx hy))
```

This doesn't look like the standard indentation style to me:
```suggestion
  induction hy using adjoin_induction with
  | mem z hz =>
    induction hx using adjoin_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact mem_mem _ h _ hz
    | zero => exact zero_left _ _
    | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | smul _ _ _ h => exact smul_left _ _ _ _ _ h
  | zero => exact zero_right x hx
  | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | smul _ _ _ h => exact smul_right _ _ _ _ _ h
```
Is this the only "weird" induction principle? If so, I think an `example` after it showing how to use it would be a good idea.
Should `s` be explicit, do you think? This would allow the user to defer the proof of `closure s = âŠ¤` into the arms of the induction without creating a metavariable.
What would the `example` look like if this were explicit?
`induction x using dense_induction s`
I've made `s` explicit and added an example.

```suggestion
  | mem z hz => induction hx using closure_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact mem _ h _ hz
    | one => exact one_left _ (subset_closure hz)
    | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | inv _ _ h => exact inv_left _ _ _ (subset_closure hz) h
  | one => exact one_right x hx
  | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_right _ _ _ _ _ hx hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | inv _ _ h => exact inv_right _ _ _ _ h
```

```suggestion
  | mem z hz => induction hx using closure_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact mem _ h _ hz
    | one => exact one_left _ (subset_closure hz)
    | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | one => exact one_right x hx
  | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_right _ _ _ _ _ hx hâ‚ hâ‚‚
```

```suggestion
  | mem z hz => induction hy using closure_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact mem _ hz _ h
    | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_left _ _ _ _ _ hy hâ‚ hâ‚‚
```

```suggestion
  | mem z hz => induction hx using closure_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact mem_mem _ h _ hz
    | zero => exact zero_left _ _
    | one => exact one_left _ _
    | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | neg _ _ h => exact neg_left _ _ _ _ h
  | zero => exact zero_right x hx
  | one => exact one_right x hx
  | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | neg _ _ h => exact neg_right _ _ _ _ h
```

```suggestion
      | mem x hx =>
        induction hx using Submonoid.closure_induction with
        | mem _ h => exact subset_closure h
```

```suggestion
  | mem z hz => induction hx using closure_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact mem_mem _ h _ hz
    | zero => exact zero_left _ _
    | one => exact one_left _ _
    | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | zero => exact zero_right x hx
  | one => exact one_right x hx
  | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
```

```suggestion
  | mem z hz => induction ha using adjoin_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact mem_mem _ h _ hz
    | algebraMap _ => exact algebraMap_left _ _ hz
    | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | star _ _ h => exact star_left _ _ _ _ h
  | algebraMap r =>
    induction ha using adjoin_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact algebraMap_right _ _ h
    | algebraMap _ => exact algebraMap_both _ _
    | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | star _ _ h => exact star_left _ _ _ _ h
  | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | star _ _ h => exact star_right _ _ _ _ h
```

```suggestion
  | mem z hz => induction ha using span_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact mem_mem _ h _ hz
    | zero => exact zero_left _ _
    | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | smul _ _ _ h => exact smul_left _ _ _ _ _ h
  | zero => exact zero_right a ha
  | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | smul _ _ _ h => exact smul_right _ _ _ _ _ h
```

```suggestion
  | mem z hz => induction hx using adjoin_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact mem_mem _ h _ hz
    | algebraMap _ => exact algebraMap_left _ _ hz
    | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | algebraMap r =>
    induction hx using adjoin_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact algebraMap_right _ _ h
    | algebraMap _ => exact algebraMap_both _ _
    | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
```

```suggestion
    | mem x hx => exact mem x hx
    | zero => exact zero
    | add x y hx hy hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | neg x hx h => exact neg _ h
    | mul x y hx hy hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
```

```suggestion
  | mem z hz => induction hx using closure_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact mem_mem _ h _ hz
    | zero => exact zero_left _ _
    | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | neg _ _ h => exact neg_left _ _ _ _ h
  | zero => exact zero_right x hx
  | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | neg _ _ h => exact neg_right _ _ _ _ h
```

```suggestion
  | mem z hz => induction hx using closure_induction with
    | mem _ h => exact mem_mem _ h _ hz
    | zero => exact zero_left _ _
    | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
    | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_left _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | zero => exact zero_right x hx
  | mul _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact mul_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
  | add _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚ => exact add_right _ _ _ _ _ _ hâ‚ hâ‚‚
```

```suggestion
    dense_induction _ hs hmul fun y => by rw [one_mul, h1, one_mul]
```
untested, but this looks like the sort of explicit insertion that isn't really doing anything?
I thought the same thing. It's necessary, but I'm not sure why. Note that it was already there.
Maybe it forces the elaboration order to change, which turns out to be necessary here

It's the proliferation of underscores in things like this that I was also worried about - we go from writing `mul` as the term to writing `(fun _ _ _ _ â†¦ mul _ _)` instead. Like I say, I don't think this is a huge problem, but it can make these induction lemmas more awkward to use in practice: here and in the proof of `closureCommMonoidOfComm` (which is the next thing in the git diff in this file), it's quite a bit less clear what's going on. In fact, for the not-particularly-similar case of finite sums, I wanted to introduce a non-dependent version for exactly this reason (Finset.sum_nbij), which turned out to be really practical. 

Again though, I won't block on this, the change in this PR is clearly overall positive.

I think the idea is that you probably should be using `induction _ using closure_induction` instead of `refine closure_induction ..` in which case the underscore proliferation is less bad; but @j-loreaux deliberately did not make that change in this PR to reduce the overall diff.

Indeed, for the most part I didn't switch to `induction _ using closure_induction` in order to keep the diff small (Although in the case of `closureCommMonoidOfComm`, it's just that it was low in the hierarchy and I didn't realize yet that those should be switched for readability).

As for `iSup_induction`, part of the problem is that it's *not* dependent, when it should be. Note that there is `iSup_induction'` which *is* dependent. I didn't do the replacement for those lemmas as well because I was trying to keep the changes pared down to the `closure/adjoin/span_induction` lemmas.

Here is a proof of the dependent version of `iSup_induction`. Note that using `key` to deal with the motive is essential, but this is not surprising because `â¨† i, S i` isn't defeq to `closure s` for some `s`. That's essentially why `iSup_induction` is it's own lemma in the first place.
```lean
theorem iSup_induction {Î¹ : Sort*} (S : Î¹ â†’ Submonoid M) {C : (x : M) â†’ (x âˆˆ â¨† i, S i) â†’ Prop}
    (mem : âˆ€ (i) (x) (hx : x âˆˆ S i), C x (mem_iSup_of_mem i hx)) (one : C 1 (one_mem _))
    (mul : âˆ€ x hx y hy, C x hx â†’ C y hy â†’ C (x * y) (mul_mem hx hy))
    {x : M} (hx : x âˆˆ â¨† i, S i) : C x hx := by
  have key {y} : y âˆˆ â¨† i, S i â†” y âˆˆ closure (â‹ƒ i, (S i : Set M)) := by simp only [iSup_eq_closure]
  show C x (key.mpr (key.mp hx))
  refine closure_induction ?_ ?_ ?_ (key.mp hx)
  all_goals simpa [â† key, forall_comm (Î² := Î¹)]
```

Indeed, `iSup_induction` isn't dependent, but that's exactly the situation I'm worried about: when you need to prove something which is not dependent, but all you have access to is a dependent induction
But why do we want the non-dependent versions at all? They don't `elab_as_elim` properly because Lean can't compute the motive.

Oh, for applications where you want to prove something that's not an induction lemma, you just want to use the induction lemma to help you get there. In these cases, the motive could be (and is often) non-dependent
We discussed this and agreed that this was not an issue for *induction principles*, but for other lemmas it can be quite useful to have non-dependent versions.
I claim we should probably deprecate this; it was only useful in the absence of the dependent principle.

I left one of these (for `StarSubalgebra`) around without deprecation because it was being used in a way where it was actually necessary (i.e., using the non-subtype version would have been very painful).

To me it seems a little inconsistent that the induction principle / motive takes `a b ha hb`, but the `add` and `smul` induction hypotheses takes `a ha b hb`. Maybe this is too annoying to change in this PR, but it would be make them consistent one way or the other eventually.

I slightly favor the `a b ha hb` ordering, since in context this is used as `a b ha hb iha ihb` which is a little more consistent than `a ha b hb iha ihb`. `a ha iha b hb ihb` would of course also be an option.
oof, yeah, that's going to be an annoying change, but I can do it if we agree on the ordering. Are you okay with `a b ha hb iha ihb`?
I don't want to hold up the merging of this PR (I'm currently ploughing through it all just to check there's nothing which stands out as weird) but could you have used `-` instead of `_hx` here?

Why are we having to use `(hx :=` here and in a few other places? Is this evidence that some implicit argument should be explicit? This PR certainly wasn't scared to add many new `_` inputs! (due to its nature).

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - refactor: migrate to dependent induction lemmas

</details>

* The induction principle was not dependent, and should have been
* The induction principle has the arguments in the wrong order
* `elab_as_elim` is missing from the theorem
* You tried to use `apply` with an `elab_as_elim`

> You should never have to specify the motive explicitly though? 

Note that the current state of this PR has exactly one adaptation going from the non-dependent to the dependent one, in `dense_induction`. And the motive is specified explicitly here, in a non-dependent way: exactly the situation I'm worried about. 
It's possible that this is an isolated example, but I just want to flag it because it does get annoying in practice.

@b-mehta I *think* that `refine` can get confused, but that's primarily because `dense_induction` is weird in that the term on which we are doing induction (namely `x`) doesn't reference `s` in it's type, so it's a bit underdetermined. ```lean
```lean
theorem dense_induction {p : M â†’ Prop} {s : Set M} (hs : closure s = âŠ¤)
    (mem : âˆ€ x âˆˆ s, p x)
    (mul : âˆ€ x y, p x â†’ p y â†’ p (x * y))
    (x : M) : p x := by
  induction hs.symm â–¸ mem_top x using closure_induction with
  | mem x hx => exact mem x hx
  | mul x _ y _ hpx hpy => exact mul x y hpx hpy
```

Overall, while it was a lot of work to go through changing things, it wasn't terrible. This `dense_induction` issue hardly ever came up (at least in terms of *new* places where I needed to specify the motive). You're welcome to have a look and let me know what you think.
I think all the primed induction principles should be kept as deprecated aliases, to not break downstream code that already uses them.

> I think all the primed induction principles should be kept as deprecated aliases, to not break downstream code that already uses them.

I considered that, but I think it might be really confusing if we *only* swap the names on some of them.

> > I think all the primed induction principles should be kept as deprecated aliases, to not break downstream code that already uses them.
> 
> I considered that, but I think it might be really confusing if we _only_ swap the names on some of them.

I'm not suggesting we swap the names, but that both the primed and unprimed versions refer to the dependent ones. That way people don't have to guess to work out that they just need to remove the `'`.

> I'm not suggesting we swap the names, but that both the primed and unprimed versions refer to the dependent ones. That way people don't have to guess to work out that they just need to remove the `'`

Done

ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by b-mehta.

Given that this PR is huge, I thoroughly approve of the changes, my questions above are quite superficial and probably easily answered, and this might pick up merge conflicts if we leave it too long, my instinct is to merge first and ask questions later.

bors merge
